skill.name: gtars
skill.description: High-performance toolkit for genomic interval analysis in Rust with Python bindings. Use when working with genomic regions, BED files, coverage tracks, overlap detection, tokenization for ML models, or fragment analysis in computational genomics and machine learning applications.
skill.summary: High-performance toolkit for genomic interval analysis in Rust with Python bindings. Use when workin...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate genomic interval analysis toolkit. All documentation describes standard bioinformatics operations. No malicious code patterns, network exfiltration, credential access, or obfuscation detected. The tool performs file I/O for genomic formats only.

content.user_title: Analyze genomic intervals and coverage tracks
content.value_statement: Genomic interval analysis requires specialized tools for processing BED files, detecting overlaps, and generating coverage tracks. Gtars provides high-performance Rust implementations with Python bindings for computational genomics and machine learning workflows.
actual_capabilities: Detect overlaps between genomic intervals using IGD indexing
Generate coverage tracks from sequencing data (WIG, BigWig formats)
Tokenize genomic regions for machine learning applications
Manage reference genome sequences with GA4GH refget protocol
Split and analyze single-cell fragment files by barcodes
Score fragment overlaps against reference datasets
limitations: Requires Rust/Cargo for CLI installation, Python bindings for library use
Does not perform sequence alignment or variant calling
Limited to standard genomic formats (BED, WIG, BigWig, FASTA)
Does not include visualization or plotting capabilities

use_cases.title: Peak Overlap Analysis
use_cases.description: Identify overlapping regulatory elements between ChIP-seq peaks and gene annotations.

use_cases.title: Genomic ML Preprocessing
use_cases.description: Convert genomic coordinates to discrete tokens for transformer models and deep learning.

use_cases.title: Fragment Processing
use_cases.description: Split ATAC-seq fragments by cell barcodes and perform cluster-based analysis.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Overlap Query
prompt_templates.prompt: Use gtars to find overlaps between two BED files: chip_peaks.bed and promoters.bed. Show regions that overlap.

prompt_templates.title: Coverage Generation
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a BigWig coverage track from atac_fragments.bed using gtars uniwig with 10bp resolution.

prompt_templates.title: ML Tokenization
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a TreeTokenizer from training_regions.bed and tokenize these genomic coordinates for a genomic transformer model.

prompt_templates.title: Fragment Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Split fragments.tsv by clusters.txt and generate coverage tracks for each cluster using gtars.

output_examples.input: Find overlaps between chip_peaks.bed and promoters.bed using gtars
output: Found 245 peaks overlapping with promoter regions
Top overlapping chromosomes: chr1 (89), chr2 (52), chr3 (38)

best_practices: Build IGD indexes once and reuse for repeated queries to improve performance
Use BigWig format instead of WIG for large datasets to reduce file size and enable efficient random access
Enable parallel processing for files with more than 100,000 regions
anti_patterns: Processing unvalidated BED files without checking chromosome names match your reference
Running coverage analysis at single-base resolution on whole-genome data without memory considerations
Using tokenizers without understanding the resolution parameter impact on downstream ML models

faq.question: What Python version is required?
faq.answer: Gtars requires Python 3.8 or later. Python 3.10+ recommended for best performance.

faq.question: Can this run on Windows?
faq.answer: Python bindings work on Windows via pip. CLI tools require Rust compilation which is supported on Windows through WSL.

faq.question: How much memory is needed?
faq.answer: Memory usage depends on dataset size. For 1M regions, plan for 2-4GB RAM. Use streaming for larger files.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Gtars processes data locally. No data is sent to external servers. All file I/O is user-controlled.

faq.question: Why is my query slow?
faq.answer: Build an IGD index before querying. Enable parallel processing with --threads flag. Use memory-mapped mode for large files.

faq.question: How does this compare to BEDTools?
faq.answer: Gtars offers Rust-based performance with Python bindings. Similar overlap detection but adds tokenization for ML and BigWig support.
